I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  to  India  for  the  Himachal  Pradesh  Clean  Energy 
Transmission  Investment  Program.1 The  report  also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance 
(TA)  for  the  Himachal  Pradesh  Power  Sector  Capacity  Development  and  Implementation 
Support, and if the Board approves the proposed MFF, I, acting under the authority delegated to 
me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
2. 
The investment program will fund electric transmission system upgrades and expansion 
in the state of Himachal Pradesh, India. Outputs will be new transmission substations and high 
voltage transmission  lines.  A  capacity  development  component  will  benefit  the  state’s recently 
formed,  stand-alone  transmission  utility,  H.P.  Power  Transmission  Corporation  Limited 
(HPPTCL), and thus assist the state to achieve its power sector reform objectives, which include 
the formation of an independent transmission utility.2 
 

II. 

THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

A. 

Rationale  

Background. Himachal Pradesh, a small mountainous state with a population of slightly 
3. 
over 6.8 million, has abundant water resources in the five major rivers flowing through the state 
from  the  western  Himalayas.  The  hydropower  generation  potential  of  Himachal  Pradesh  is 
about  23,000  megawatts  (MW)—about  one-fourth  of  the  total  hydropower  potential  of  India. 
Power generation capacity located within Himachal Pradesh consists solely of hydropower, with 
about 6,256 MW of capacity installed as of December 2010. In its Hydropower Policy, 2006,3 the 
Government  of  Himachal  Pradesh  (GOHP)  targets  its  comparative  advantage  in  hydropower 
with the goal  to  become  the  ―hydropower  state‖ of the  country. This  development  will  not  only 
benefit  Himachal  Pradesh,  but  will  provide  a  clean  indigenous  source  of  energy  to  assist  in 
meeting the country’s rapidly increasing energy demand resulting from its high economic growth 
and aim to provide electricity for all its citizens. 
 
Sector road map and investment program. The state’s power sector road map covers 
4. 
power generation, transmission and distribution, regulatory matters, and capacity building. The 
road  map’s  emphasis  is  to  encourage  investment  in  hydropower  generation—the  majority  of 
which  are  run-of-river  type—and  articulates  that  Himachal  Pradesh  must  build  out  its  electric 
transmission infrastructure so that the additional hydropower can be efficiently transmitted within 
and  outside  the  state.  As  Himachal  Pradesh  is  one  of  the  few  states  in  India  with  100% 
electrification  at  the  village  level,  additional  hydropower  capacity  will  not  just  serve  the  state’s 
growing demand, but will serve the national grid through interstate power flows.  As a subset of 
the  overall  sector  road  map,  and  with  support  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB), 
HPPTCL  has  prepared  a  power  system  master  plan  to  articulate  a  transmission  network 
expansion  plan  for  Himachal  Pradesh.  4  This  plan,  endorsed  by  India’s  Central  Electricity

Authority  (CEA),  provides  a  sound  basis  for  investment  in  transmission  facilities,  and  is 
expected to engender confidence among existing and potential private hydropower developers 
that  sufficient  transmission  capacity  will  be  available  to  evacuate  power  from  hydropower 
facilities  to  markets  outside  of  Himachal  Pradesh.  The  investment  program  thus  consists  of 
transmission system investments required through 2016, and a capacity development program 
for  HPPTCL  to  help  corporatize  the  state  transmission  utility  as  a  stand-alone  entity—a 
requirement of the Electricity Act, 2003. 
 
Strategic  context.  The  road  map  and  investment  program  are  consistent  with  the 
5. 
development  goals  and  strategies  of  the  Government  of  India  and  ADB.  The  government’s 
Eleventh Five Year Plan, 2007–2012, includes increased infrastructure investment as a key for 
promoting  broad-based  economic  growth,  and  advocates  expanded  use  of  renewable  energy 
resources  to  increase  energy  security  and  improve  energy  efficiency  in  the  economy.  ADB’s 
Energy  Policy5 includes  increasing  energy  security  needs  and  facilitating  a  transition  to  low 
carbon economies by promoting increased renewable energy in the region’s energy mix.  Since 
the 
further  hydropower 
development in Himachal Pradesh, the investment program indirectly contributes to a reduction 
in the carbon intensity of India’s power supply mix. The road map and investment program are 
also consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2009–2012, which supports expanded 
and optimized transmission systems and institutional strengthening.6 
 
6. 
Policy framework. The Integrated Energy Policy, 2006 advocates optimizing the power 
supply  mix,  including  greater  use  of  indigenous hydropower  resources  and  renewable energy. 
Policies  specifically  related  to  hydropower  promotion  include  the  50,000  MW  Hydropower 
Initiative,  2003  and  the  New  Hydro  Policy,  2008.  At  the  state  level,  the  GOHP’s  Hydropower 
Policy,  2006  targets  the  hydropower  resources  in  the  state  and  promotes  hydropower  project 
development and its enabling infrastructure, including the transmission system. 
 
The Electricity Act, 2003 is the cornerstone legislation for the power sector in India, and 
7. 
requires  integrated  utility  companies  to  unbundle  into  separate  generation,  transmission,  and 
distribution  entities.  In  2006,  the  GOHP  formed  the  Himachal  Pradesh  Power  Corporation 
Limited as the state’s generating company, and in 2008 formed the HPPTCL as a stand-alone 
transmission utility company. The old Himachal Pradesh State Electricity Board  has become a 
corporation  and  will  serve  as  the  state’s  distribution  utility.  While  this  process  has  been 
progressing since 2006, the legal order issued on 10 June 2010 formally recognized HPPTCL 
as  the  state  transmission  utility.  The  state  also  has  an  independent  regulator  since  2000, 
Himachal  Pradesh  Electricity  Regulatory  Commission  (HPERC),  which  determines  tariffs  and 
regulates these new entities in accordance with regulatory guidelines from the Central Electricity 
Regulatory Commission. 
 
Rationale  for  ADB  partnership  and  multitranche  financing  facility.  The  MFF 
8. 
supports a well-defined investment program underpinned by continued institutional reform and a 
delineated  sector  road  map.  The  state’s  investment  program  objectives  require  a  flexible 
modality  that  allows  financing  of  individual  investments  as  projects  and conditions  warrant,  by 
linking financing to project readiness and capacity. The MFF is a suitable modality as it provides 
up-front  support  to  the  GOHP  for  its  substantial  development  program,  but  with  financial 
commitments  sequenced  to  match  project  readiness.  As  the  sequenced  investments  are 
implemented, expertise will build over time and will allow future projects to benefit directly from

 Impact and Outcome 

implementation  experience  gained  from  the  initial  investments  and  from  the  capacity 
development  component.  It  also  allows  ADB  to  engage  with  the  GOHP  in  a  continuous  long-
term dialogue consistent with the clean energy policies of the Government of India and ADB. 
 
Lessons.  A  sector  assistance  program  evaluation  on  the  energy  sector  in  India, 
9. 
conducted in 2007, identifies lessons learned from previous ADB assistance.7 Lessons identified 
include (i) ADB’s approach to lending at the state level has worked well and should be used as 
a  model  for  future  assistance,  (ii)  sustained  TA  is  needed  to  support  state-level  sector  goals, 
and (iii) corporatization is providing benefits similar to those normally attributed to privatization 
by  introducing  commercially  and  financially  sustainable  principles  and  better  governance  into 
state  entities.  These  experiences  are  reflected  in  the  design  and  preparation  of  the  proposed 
MFF, including TA and capacity development for the state transmission utility. 
 
B. 
 
10. 
The  investment  program’s  impact  will  be  that  the  Himachal  Pradesh  power  sector 
transmits clean energy to end users in Himachal Pradesh and the rest of India. The outcome will 
be  that  HPPTCL  has  sufficient  assets  and  capacity  to  support  its  mandate  as  the  state 
transmission utility company. 
 
C. 
 
11. 
The investment program’s outputs will include two major areas: (i) physical investments 
in  transmission  infrastructure,  including  high  voltage  lines  and  transmission  substations; 8 and 
(ii) capacity development for the state transmission utility company. The additional transmission 
capacity to be added by this investment program is sufficient to transmit power to electrify  over 
456,000  homes  in  India,  and  includes  about  125  kilometers  of  transmission  lines  and  over 
12,000  MW  of  additional  substation  capacity.  Specifically,  the  first  project  of  the  investment 
program will fund the four investment components shown below.

Investment and Financing Plans 

Capacity development activities will strengthen procurement, financial management, and 
13. 
project monitoring capacity; and support HPPTCL staff to manage its growing asset size. It will 
also  fund  a  computerized  enterprise  resource  planning  solution  covering  accounting  and 
management  information  system  applications;  and  will  finance  the  purchase  of  software, 
hardware, training, and initial system maintenance. 
 
D. 
 
The  GOHP’s  investment  program  is  estimated  to  cost  about  $438  million.  The 
14. 
Government  of  India  has  requested  an  MFF  in  an  amount  up  to  $350  million  from  ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources to help finance part of the investment program. The MFF is expected 
to have three tranches, with tranche 1 ($113 million) scheduled for 2011, and two more tranches 
estimated  at  $80  million  and  $157  million  each  for  2012  through  2014,  subject  to  the 
government’s  submission  of  related  periodic  financing  requests,  execution  of  the  related  loan 
and  project  agreements  for  each  tranche,  and  fulfillment  of  terms  and  conditions  and 
undertakings set forth in the framework financing agreement. Individual loans will include taxes 
and  duties  for  the  investment  components,9 as  well  as  imbedded  costs  in  supply  and  erection 
contracts such as transport (including local transport), freight, and insurance costs. The central 
government  will  make  the  ADB  loan  proceeds  in  each  tranche  available  to  the  state 
government, which will relend the proceeds to HPPTCL, in each case on terms and conditions 
consistent with Indian legislation and acceptable to ADB.

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

17. 
HPPTCL  will  be  the  executing  agency  as  well  as  the  implementing  agency  for  the 
investment  program,  responsible  for  supervising  subproject  implementation  and  monitoring  of 
subproject  operational  performance.  For  these  purposes,  HPPTCL  has  established  a  project 
management unit located at HPPTCL’s headquarters in Shimla, Himachal Pradesh. The project 
management unit is headed by a project director, and includes staff located at headquarters and 
in the field at project sites. As HPPTCL was established in 2008 as part of the unbundling of the 
former  state  integrated  utility  company  (Himachal  Pradesh  State  Electricity  Board),  HPPTCL 
retains  staff  and  considerable  transmission  system  planning  and  operational  experience  from 
the  Himachal  Pradesh  State  Electricity  Board,  and  currently  has  130  employees.  The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in Table  3 and described in detail in the facility 
administration manual (FAM).10

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

19. 
All investment projects under the investment program will be subject to rigorous scrutiny, 
as they are first examined by HPPTCL and then by the CEA for their technical, economic, and 
financial  feasibility.  ADB  will  also  review  all  aspects,  including  visiting  sites,  reviewing  all 
available  reports,  and  undertaking  a  comprehensive  due  diligence  assessment,  including 
safeguard aspects, and technical, financial, and economic viability. 
 
A. 

Technical 

20. 
All proposed transmission system components within the investment program are part of 
the power system master plan (footnote 4), which was endorsed by the CEA. This plan included 
several  interrelated  elements,  including  forecasting  power  demand  growth,  distribution  system 
planning, formulating the generation expansion plan, the river basin plan, and the transmission 
system expansion plan. The design of the electricity infrastructure considered the security and 
reliability of the electricity supply via the transmission system, and involved a long-term view in 
determining least-cost options for optimizing the system. 
 
ADB  has  reviewed  and  confirmed  the  technical  viability  of  the  tranche  1  loan 
21. 
investments. Project designs are consistent with overall least-cost expansion plans; and reflect 
best-practice design, construction, and operation and maintenance (O&M) features.

licensees  and  ultimately  end-use  customers  at  the  state  level).  The  aggregate  revenue 
requirement, which will be confirmed by HPERC, will recover the full cost of loan capital by way 
of  accelerated  depreciation  (to  cover  the  bulk  of  principal  repayments  over  12  years)  and 
interest, return on equity, O&M expenses, and interest on working capital. 
 
23. 
Financial  analysis  of  all  tranches  under  the  investment  program  will  be  carried  out  in 
accordance with ADB’s Financial Management and Analysis of Projects.13 Financial viability will 
be  examined  by  comparing  the  incremental  costs  and  benefits  of  the  ―with-investment‖  and 
―without-investment‖  scenarios.  Cost  streams  used  for  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR) 
determination  reflect  the  costs  of  delivering  the  estimated  benefits,  and  include  capital 
investment,  income  tax,  and  O&M.  Benefits  flow  to  HPPTCL  through  revenue  accruing  from 
tariffs earned from transmission of electricity through the transmission assets. The investment’s 
FIRR will be compared to the weighted average cost of capital of the proposed investments to 
HPPTCL. Sensitivity of the FIRR to adverse movements in the underlying assumptions will also 
be assessed. For the tranche 1 project, the FIRR of 6% exceeded the weighted average cost of 
capital of 4.3%, so the tranche 1 investments are deemed financially viable.14 
 
24. 
Economic analysis. Projects financed by the investment program, as part of the state’s 
power  system  master  plan,  are  integral  components  of  the  least-cost  plan  to  achieve  desired 
long-term  outcomes  for  power  system  expansion  in  Himachal  Pradesh.  A  time-slice  approach 
was adopted for detailed economic cost–benefit analysis, considering the entire power system 
master  plan’s  generation  and  transmission  investment  plans,  2012–2016.  This  was  done  to 
avoid  the  difficulties  inherent  in  allocating  costs  and  particularly  benefits  to  individual 
transmission components in an increasingly interconnected network. 
 
25. 
Electricity  generated  and  transmitted  from  hydropower  assets  built  under  the  master 
plan  will  be  used  to  meet  any  unserved  demand  for  electricity  in  Himachal  Pradesh  and  the 
northern  region  of  the  national  grid.  When  there  is  no  unserved  demand,  this  electricity  will 
displace more expensive sources of generation in the northern region—primarily diesel captive 
plants and coal-fired plants. Non-incremental outputs from the investment program are valued at 
the  resource  cost  savings  that  would  accrue  if  the  investment  plan  proceeds.  Incremental 
outputs  are  valued  using  Himachal  Pradesh  and  northern  region  consumers’  estimated 
willingness  to  pay  for  incremental  consumption,  adjusted  for  medium  voltage  and  low  voltage 
losses as appropriate. The basis for economic evaluation is a comparison of benefits and costs 
between  the  with-  and  without-investment  scenarios.  Investment  is  assumed  to  take  place 
during  2012–2016,  and  benefits  are  assumed  to  be  realized  progressively  from  2013.  The 
detailed cost–benefit calculations show that the overall investment master plan is economically 
viable,  with an  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  24.9%. This  robust return  reflects 
the high economic value of hydropower in India.15

D. 
 
30. 
Adequate  power  supply  is  essential  to  sustain  economic  growth,  and  regular  and 
efficient power supply is correlated to poverty reduction. Indian states like Gujarat, Haryana, and 
Punjab,  with high  levels  of  power generation  and  consumption,  also  have lower  poverty  rates. 
The benefits of improving the power sector are manifold. Technical developments and reforms 
that lead to sector sustainability can free up resources for other pro-poor initiatives. Greater and 
more reliable power supply helps bolster social services, as hospitals, schools, and other social 
entities  often  suffer  most  from  low-quality  power  supply  and  load  shedding.  Socially,  efficient 
power  supply  increases  access  to  electronic  media  such  as  television  and  radio,  allowing  a 
greater understanding of civic affairs and better informed choices. For the economy of India, a 
developed  power  sector  boosts  farm  mechanization  and  agricultural  yield,  and  benefits  the 
commercial  and  industrial  sectors  through  business  expansion  and  more  employment 
opportunities. With regular electrification, household and cottage industries would also increase 
and improve. During construction, the investment program is expected to generate employment 
in Himachal Pradesh of both skilled and unskilled labor, which can include women workers.

 Safeguards 

E. 
 
31. 
An  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework,  a  resettlement  framework,  and 
indigenous peoples planning framework outline the governing environment and social safeguard 
principles and requirements for the projects financed by the investment program.16 HPPTCL will 
undertake  environmental  and  social  safeguard  due  diligence  on  all  projects  based  on  these 
frameworks and submit annual reports on implementation of environmental management plans 
(EMPs) and resettlement plans for projects, and if required, indigenous peoples plans. HPPTCL 
has  its  own  board-approved  safeguards  policies:  (i)  the  Environment  and  Social  Safeguards 
Policy; and (ii) the Resettlement, Relief, Rehabilitation and Compensation Policy. These policies 
were taken into consideration in preparing the environmental assessment and review framework 
and resettlement framework. 
 
32. 
The tranche 1 project is environment category B. The civil construction work is limited to 
building  foundations  for  the  transmission  towers,  and  substations,  and  the  tranche  1  project 
does  not  come  within  any  environmentally  sensitive  area.  Based  on  the  environmental 
assessment and surveys, associated potential adverse environmental impacts are minimal and 
can  be mitigated through  implementation  of the EMP.  An adequate  budgetary  provision  in the 
tranche  1  project  covers  the  environmental  mitigation  and  monitoring  requirements,  and  the 
EMP is part of the construction contracts. HPPTCL will supervise the construction contracts and 
EMP  implementation,  and  semiannual  progress reports  of  its  implementation  will  be  submitted 
to  ADB.  Overall,  the  major  social  and  environmental  impacts  associated  with  the  tranche  1 
project  are  limited  to  the  construction  period  and  can  be  mitigated  to  an  acceptable  level  by 
implementation  of  recommended  engineering  measures  and  environmental  practices.  Future 
tranches are expected to be environment category B based on investigations conducted to date, 
which will be confirmed during detailed due diligence conducted for each tranche. 
 
33. 
The  tranche  1  project  is  involuntary  resettlement  category  B  and  indigenous  peoples 
category  C.  Census  surveys  and  consultations  were  undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  Indicative  and  expected  categorization  for  all  future 
tranches  is  involuntary  resettlement  category  B  and  indigenous  peoples  category  C  based  on 
subproject reviews to date, which will be confirmed during investment program implementation. 
The  tranche  1  project  will  entail  minimum  private  land  acquisition.  Of  the  three  proposed 
substations,  two  are  to  be  built  on  government  land,  and  the  third  requires  2.5  hectares  of 
private  land.  The  transmission  line  will  have  76 towers,  out  of  which  63  will  be  located  on 
privately  owned  land,  10  towers  will  be  placed  on  government  land,  and  the  remaining  three 
towers  will  be  placed  on  community  land.  No  structures  or  buildings  will  be  affected  and  no 
physical displacement is foreseen. In total, the tranche 1 project includes the acquisition of 3.65 
hectares  of  private  land.  Regarding  gender  issues,  the  loan  agreements  include  a  standard 
assurance related to core labor standards for contractors (including equal pay for equal type of 
work), and an awareness program on HIV and sexually transmitted diseases.17
